com.pump.image.transition

Class AbstractPlanarTransition2D

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.pump.image.transition.AbstractTransition
      • com.pump.image.transition.Transition2D
        • com.pump.image.transition.AbstractPlanarTransition2D
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Transition
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    SwivelTransition2D, ZoomTransition2D

    public abstract class AbstractPlanarTransition2D
extends Transition2D
    Here 2 frames slide around on an imaginary table top extending into the distance. This creates a 3D-type effect where frames move in and out of the users field of view.

    (The best way to understand exactly what this does is to see it in action.)

    More technically: this creates a PerspectiveTransform and projects two dots into the plane stretching into the distance, and then this positions the two frames based on those dots.

      • getInstructions

        public Transition2DInstruction[] getInstructions(float progress,
                                                 java.awt.Dimension size)
        Description copied from class: Transition2D
        This determines how to transition from A to B.
        Specified by:
        getInstructions in class Transition2D
        Parameters:
        progress - a float from [0,1]. When this is zero, these instructions should render the initial frame. When this is one, these instructions should render the final frame.

      • getFrameALocation

        public abstract java.awt.geom.Point2D getFrameALocation(float p)
        This should be a dot within the rectangle (0,0,1,1). Imagine the rectangle is a diagram of a stage (you know, a theatrical stage, facing an audience). When the point is (.5,1), this frame is exactly centered in the user's field of view. At (.5,0) this frame is centered, but small -- as if in the distance. So the y-coordinate is used to represent depth, and the x-coordinate is used to represent horizontal movement.

      • getFrameBLocation

        public abstract java.awt.geom.Point2D getFrameBLocation(float p)
        This should be a dot within the rectangle (0,0,1,1). Imagine the rectangle is a diagram of a stage (you know, a theatrical stage, facing an audience). When the point is (.5,1), this frame is exactly centered in the user's field of view. At (.5,0) this frame is centered, but small -- as if in the distance. So the y-coordinate is used to represent depth, and the x-coordinate is used to represent horizontal movement.
